intro: Phormium atropurpureum, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a striking plant native to New Zealand. It is a perennial shrub that belongs to the Asphodelaceae family, characterized by its sword-shaped, fibrous leaves. The plant produces tall spikes of purple or red flowers during the summer months, adding visual interest to its appearance. Its fibrous leaves have historically been used by Māori for making textiles and other crafts. The plant is also valued in horticulture for its ornamental qualities and ability to thrive in a variety of soil conditions.
